fields.value: Labor Demand Elasticity Measures for US Counties by Industries

dsDescriptionValue.value: This dataset comes from the study "REGIONAL VARIATIONS IN LABOR DEMAND ELASTICITY: EVIDENCE FROM U.S. COUNTIES" by Abhradeep Maiti and Debarshi Indra (Journal of Regional Science. doi: 10.1111/jors.12265). The file contains the estimated labor demand elasticity for various industry groups across US counties.

keywordValue.value: Labor Demand Elasticity in the US

fields.value:
Maiti, A. and Indra, D. (2016), REGIONAL VARIATIONS IN LABOR DEMAND ELASTICITY: EVIDENCE FROM U.S. COUNTIES. Journal of Regional Science. doi: 10.1111/jors.12265 

We use a large panel dataset covering the period 1988â€“2010 to estimate county specific own-wage elasticity of labor demand in the U.S. for four highly aggregated industries: construction, finance/insurance/real-estate/service, manufacturing, and retail trade. Our estimation of a random parameter panel data model yields significant evidence of spatial variations in wage elasticity of labor demand. We relate the spatial variation in elasticity to differences in county characteristics like industry specialization, industry competition, levels of natural amenity and urbanization. Using a regression discontinuity approach we also find that pro-business states have higher labor demand elasticity.
